verb.description: Strengthen or support physically or mentally.
examples: this thought had sustained him throughout the years
synonyms: be a source of strength to
be a tower of strength to

verb.description: Undergo or suffer (something unpleasant, especially an injury)
examples: he died after sustaining severe head injuries

verb.description: Cause to continue or be prolonged for an extended period or without interruption.
examples: he cannot sustain a normal conversation

verb.description: Uphold, affirm, or confirm the justice or validity of.
examples: the allegations of discrimination were sustained

noun.description: An effect or facility on a keyboard or electronic instrument whereby a note can be sustained after the key is released.

origin: Middle English: from Old French soustenir, from Latin sustinere, from sub- from below + tenere hold.
